sections.heading: Background
sections.content:
Defined as sodium concentration <135meq/L [1]
Patients often not symptomatic until <120meq/L, although this level varies by patients and may be higher if the change occurred abruptly [2]
Too fast of sodium correction (>10 mmol/L/day), especially if chronic, can cause osmotic demyelination syndrome (central pontine myelinolysis) [3]

sections.heading: Hyponatremia Symptoms by Severity[2]
sections.content: Severity NOT severe Moderately severe Severe Symptoms Gait disturbances Falls Concentration Cognitive deficits Nausea without vomiting Confusion Headache Vomiting Cardiorespiratory distress Abnormal and deep somnolence Seizures Coma (GCS <8)

sections.heading: Symptoms from Rapid Correction of Sodium
sections.content:
CHF
Osmotic demyelination syndrome (central pontine myelinolysis) Altered mental status Dysphagia Dysarthria Paresis

sections.heading: Renal Causes
sections.content:
Thiazide diuretic use
Na-wasting nephropathy ( RTA , CKD)
Osmotic diuresis ( glucose , urea)
Aldosterone deficiency

sections.heading: Extra-renal Causes
sections.content:
GI loss
3rd space loss
Burns
Pancreatitis
Peritonitis

sections.heading: Hypervolemic
sections.content:
Urinary Na >20 Renal failure
Urinary Na <20 Nephrotic syndrome Cirrhosis CHF

sections.heading: Euvolemic
sections.content:
SIADH urine sodium is greater than 20-40 mEq/L
Pain, stress, nausea
Psychogenic polydipsia
Hypothyroidism
Drugs [4] [5] NSAIDs , sulfonylurea , bupropion
H 2 0 intoxication
Glucocorticoid deficiency

sections.heading: Pseudohyponatremia
sections.content:
Hyperglycemia Na+ decreases by 2.4mEq/L for each 100mg/dL increase in glucose over 100mg/dL [6]
Displaced sodium in lab specimen Hyperlipidemia Hyperproteinemia

sections.heading: Work-Up
sections.content:
Prior to giving treatment
Urine Urinalysis Urine electrolytes (Urine sodium) Urine urea urine uric acid urine osmolality urine creatinine
Serum Chemistry including Ca/Mg/Phos Serum osmolality Uric acid TSH Cortisol

sections.heading: Diagnosis
sections.content:
True serum sodium (corrected) based on serum glucose [2]
Algorithm for hyponatremia diagnosis
Correct for glucose (see table)
Determine volume status
Calculated osm (in true hyponatremia the osm is reduced)

sections.heading: Hypertonic Hyponatremia
sections.content:
Defined as osmolarity > 295mmol/L with the following causes:
Hyperglycemia Sodium decreases by 2.4mEq/L for each 100mg/dL increase in glucose over 100mg/dL [6]
Mannitol excess

sections.heading: Isotonic (pseudo) hyponatremia
sections.content:
Defined as osmolarity > 275-295mmol/L.  Often referred to as pseudo hyponatremia because the elevated lipids or proteins interfere with the laboratory sodium reading.  The following are common causes:
Hyperlipidemia
Hyperproteinemia

sections.heading: Hypotonic Hyponatremia
sections.content: Defined as an osmolarity < 275 mmol/L and categorized as hypovolemic , hypervolemic or euvolemic

sections.heading: General Management
sections.content: Must have sufficient confidence that the symptoms are caused by hyponatraemia; see Clinical Features for definition of categories.

sections.heading: NOT Severe/Moderately-Severe (Including Asymptomatic)
sections.content:
Adults: [2]
Start prompt diagnostic assessment and provide cause-specific treatment
Check serum sodium concentration after 4 hours Aim for a 5 mmol/l per 24-h increase in serum sodium concentration Limit increase to 10 mmol/l in the first 24 h (8 mmol/l during every 24 h thereafter), until a serum sodium concentration of 130 mmol/l is reached
Manage the patient as in moderately-severe symptomatic hyponatraemia if the serum sodium concentration decreases 10 mmol/l

sections.heading: Moderately Severe Symptoms
sections.content:
Adults: [2]
3% hypertonic saline 150 mL bolus over 20 min
Start prompt diagnostic assessment and provide cause-specific treatment
Check serum sodium concentration after 1, 6 and 12 hours Aim for a 5 mmol/l per 24-h increase in serum sodium concentration Limit increase to 10 mmol/l in the first 24 h (8 mmol/l during every 24 h thereafter), until a serum sodium concentration of 130 mmol/l is reached
Consider DDAVP (2mcgs IV q8h) to prevent overcorrection
Manage the patient as in severely symptomatic hyponatraemia if the serum sodium concentration further decreases despite treating the underlying diagnosis (2D).

sections.heading: Severe Symptoms
sections.content:
Adults: [2]
3% hypertonic saline 150 mL bolus over 20 min
Check serum sodium concentration after 20 min
Repeat infusion of 150 ml 3% hypertonic saline for the next 20 min
Repeat twice or until a target of 5 mmol/l increase in serum sodium concentration is achieved Each 100 mL will raise sodium by ~2 mmol/l In general, 200-400 mL of 3% hypertonic saline is reasonable dose in most adult patients with severe symptomatic hyponatremia, which may be given IV over 1-2 hr until resolution of seizures.
If you do not have 3% hypertonic saline you can give two ampules (100ml) of crash cart hypertonic bicarbonate (1 mEq/ml sodium bicarbonate equivalent to giving ~200 ml of 3% saline, which will raise the serum sodium by ~3 mM) [7] . Sodium bicarbonate should be given slowly (each ampule over 5-10 minutes).  Bicarbonate is contraindicated in patients with metabolic alkalosis.
Pediatrics: [8]
2 mL/kg  of 3% over 10-60 minutes can be infused with a repeat of up to 3 times.

sections.heading: Hypertonic hyponatremia
sections.content:
Correct underlying disorder which is often hyperglycemia [9]
Often volume depleted due to osmotic diuresis and normal saline provides adequate volume repletion

sections.heading: Isotonic (pseudo) hyponatremia
sections.content: No treatment needed [9]

sections.heading: Hypotonic hyponatremia
sections.content:
Hypovolemic Give normal saline, but be cautious of raising the serum sodium more than 10 mmol/L/day and causing osmotic demyelination syndrome (central pontine myelinolysis) [10]
Euvolemic [9] Water restrict Treat underlying cause
Hypervolemic Water restriction Diuresis Treat underlying cause

sections.heading: Calculating Sodium Replacement Therapy
sections.content: Max correction 10mEq/L in first 24hr (8 mmol/l during every 24 h thereafter), until a serum sodium concentration of 130 mmol/l is reached (lowers risk of osmotic demyelination syndrome ) [10]

sections.heading: Step 1
sections.content:
Calculate total body water
[11]
TBW(kg) = Wt(kg) x 0.6 = [Wt(lb) x 0.45] x 0.6 = Wt(lb) x 0.27

sections.heading: Step 2
sections.content:
Calculate mEq deficit
(Desired Na - Measured Na) ~ must be ≤ 10

sections.heading: Step 3
sections.content:
Calculate NS rate to be given over 24hr
NS rate (cc/hr) = TBW x mEq deficit x 0.27
If using 3% sodium chloride (to avoid volume overload) divide above rate by 3.33
Sodium Containing fluid Concentrations
Fluid type Sodium Concentration 1/2 Normal Saline 77 mEq/L Normal Saline 154 mEq/L Lactated Ringers 130 mEq/L 3% Saline 513 mEq/L

sections.heading: DDAVPCombined with Hypertonic Saline
sections.content:
Limited evidence suggests usage of DDAVP in combination with HTS can safely increase sodium, while lowering risk for over-correction [12] DDAVP prevents free water excretion renally Give 3% hypertonic saline based on calculations above Give desmopressin 1-2 µg IV q6 hours Patients must be PO water restricted
Goal sodium is 6 mEq/L over first 24 hours

sections.heading: Disposition
sections.content:
Admit if symptomatic or if Na <125mEq/L
Manage severely symptomatic patients in "an environment where close biochemical and clinical monitoring can be provided" (e.g. ICU)
